title: 111_s1020
content: The "Patient-Focused Critical Care Enhancement Act" aims to optimize critical care medicine delivery and expand the critical care workforce. The Health Resources and Services Administration's May 2006 Report to Congress highlighted the increasing demand for critical care medical services in the United States, emphasizing the importance of care delivery and organization in improving patient outcomes. The demand for critical care services in the United States is increasing, with a focus on utilizing nurses and intensivist physicians with advanced training. The aging population is driving this demand, but there is a shortage of critical care physicians which poses a threat to the quality and availability of healthcare services. The shortage of critical care physicians in the United States will disproportionately impact rural and underserved areas with suboptimal healthcare services. SEC. 4. RESEARCH. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct research through the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality to assess standardization of critical care protocols, ICU layout, equipment interoperability, staffing differences, and community approaches to critical care services. A report must be submitted to Congress within 18 months of the Act's enactment. Quality will submit a report to Congress evaluating and making recommendations on best practices in critical care medicine. SEC. 5. INNOVATIVE APPROACHES TO CRITICAL CARE SERVICES. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct demonstration projects to optimize critical care services for Medicare beneficiaries. The projects will focus on innovations in staffing, ICU arrangement, and technology utilization. Up to 5 proposals will be funded, with at least 1 focusing on training hospital-based physicians. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct projects to optimize critical care services for Medicare beneficiaries, focusing on training hospital-based physicians in rural or community hospitals. Projects will emphasize outcome measures based on quality care domains and support family assistance programs for the critically ill. The project aims to support a consortium of providers offering critical care services and a medical specialty society. Providers must measure outcomes from a family-centered approach, including communication with family members and involving them in decision-making. The impact of these initiatives will be evaluated. The project aims to evaluate the impact of a family-centered, multiprofessional team approach on family and staff satisfaction, patient stay in intensive care, and cost of care. Providers must emphasize outcome measures based on the Institute of Medicine's 6 domains of quality care. The project evaluates the impact of a family-centered, multiprofessional team approach on satisfaction, patient stay, and cost of care. Care should be timely, efficient, and equitable. SEC. 6. USE OF TELEMEDICINE TO ENHANCE CRITICAL CARE SERVICES IN RURAL AND UNDERSERVED AREAS. Amendment to Rural Utilities Service Distance Learning and Telemedicine Program to authorize additional appropriations for telemedicine critical care initiatives. "In addition to amounts authorized under section 2335A, $5,000,000 is appropriated annually from 2010 to 2015 for telemedicine initiatives in rural or medically underserved areas to enhance critical care services through telecommunications systems allowing consultation with providers not on-site. Amendment to Telehealth Network Grant Program to include critical care service delivery augmentation in rural areas." $5,000,000 annually appropriated from 2010 to 2015 for telemedicine initiatives in rural or medically underserved areas to enhance critical care services through consultation with off-site providers. Increasing the supply of critical care providers. The Public Health Service Act is amended to establish a Critical Care Initiative aiming to recruit 50 providers annually into the National Health Service Corps Loan Repayment Program. This initiative includes critical care services under the term 'primary health services'. The Public Health Service Act is amended to establish a Critical Care Initiative recruiting providers into the National Health Service Corps Loan Repayment Program, focusing on critical care services like pulmonary and critical care fellowships for physicians. Authorization of appropriations for research and demonstration projects under the Act: $5,000,000 for research and $4,000,000 for demonstration projects.
